narrative_events.description: The impoverished farmer asks the rich money-lender for the secret to wealth.
The farmer takes the sarcastic advice literally and leaves to find God (Ram).
Ram rewards the farmer with a magic wishing conch.
The Money-lender tricks the farmer into revealing the source of his luck, then steals the conch.
Unable to use the conch himself, the Money-lender forces the farmer into a deal where he gets double whatever the farmer wishes for.
The farmer wishes to lose one eye, knowing the Money-lender will lose both (double).
The Money-lender is blinded and accidentally dies as a direct result of his own greed and the farmer's wish.

motif_type: Motif K282.1: K282.1. Man contracts for load of hay on the road (without making any payment), orders the seller to deliver it at a certain inn. He then goes to the inn, sells the hay to the innkeeper, and pockets the money. The owner of the hay delivers it at the inn, tries to collect at the inn; the trickster absconds. (K. Deceptions. > K100–K299. Deceptive bargains.)

Motif K198: K198. Cheater is forced to eat excrements. Gentleman agrees to exchange his good horse for the peasant's jade, provided the peasant will eat its excrements. The peasant finds no difficulty in the task, whereas the gentleman, put to the same condition when he wants to get back his horse, finds it impossible. (K. Deceptions. > K100–K299. Deceptive bargains.)

Motif K441.3: K441.3. Fee from two persons for the same monopoly. Man to furnish goods exclusively to animal. Bargains at same time with another to do the same thing. (K. Deceptions. > K300–K499. Thefts and cheats. > K440–K499. Other cheats.)
Motif L251: L251. Beggar with small bag surpasses the one with the large. Latter refuses all but large donations; gets none. (L. Reversal of fortune. > L200–L299. Modesty brings reward.)
Motif K181: K181. Deceptive bargain: a peck of grain for each stack. The man who is to receive this share of the crop makes very small stacks. (K. Deceptions. > K100–K299. Deceptive bargains.)
atu_categories: ATU 1745: Three words at the grave (ANECDOTES AND JOKES > Jokes about Clergymen and Religious Figures > The Clergyman is Tricked (1725-1774))
ATU 1624: Thief's Excuse: the Big Wind (ANECDOTES AND JOKES > Stories about a Man > The Clever Man (1525-1639))
ATU 161: Peasant Betrays Fox by Pointing (ANIMAL TALES > Wild Animals and Humans (150-199))
ATU 859: The Penniless Bridegroom Pretends to Wealth (REALISTIC TALES > The Man Marries the Princess (850-869))

textSpan.text: There was once a farmer who suffered much at the hands of a money-lender. Good harvests, or bad, the farmer was always poor, the money-lender rich. At the last, when he hadn't a farthing left, farmer went to the money-lender's house, and said, "You can't squeeze water from a stone, and as you have nothing to get by me now, you might tell me the secret of becoming rich."

propp_functions.evidence: The impoverished farmer asks the rich money-lender for the secret to wealth.

textSpan.text:
"My friend," returned the money-lender, piously, "riches come from Ram—ask him."
"Thank you, I will!" replied the simple farmer; so he prepared three girdle-cakes to last him on the journey, and set out to find Ram.

propp_functions.evidence: The farmer takes the sarcastic advice literally and leaves to find God (Ram).

textSpan.text:
At last, he came upon a poor man sitting under a tree, and finding out he was hungry, the kindly farmer gave him his last cake, and sitting down to rest beside him, entered into conversation.
"And where are you going?" asked the poor man, at length.
"Oh, I have a long journey before me, for I am going to find Ram!" replied the farmer. "I don't suppose you could tell me which way to go?"
"Perhaps I can," said the poor man, smiling, "for I am Ram! What do you want of me?"

Then the farmer told the whole story, and Ram, taking pity on him, gave him a conch shell, and showed him how to blow it in a particular way, saying, "Remember! whatever you wish for, you have only to blow the conch that way, and your wish will be fulfilled.

propp_functions.evidence: Ram rewards the farmer with a magic wishing conch.

textSpan.text:
Therefore he went over to the simple farmer's house, and congratulated him on his good fortune, in such cunning words, pretending to have heard all about it, that before long the farmer found himself telling the whole story—all except the secret of blowing the conch, for, with all his simplicity, the farmer was not quite such a fool as to tell that.
Nevertheless, the money-lender determined to have the conch by hook or by crook, and as he was villain enough not to stick at trifles, he waited for a favourable opportunity and stole the conch.

propp_functions.evidence: The Money-lender tricks the farmer into revealing the source of his luck, then steals the conch.

textSpan.text:
Business is at a stand-still unless we make a bargain. Now, I promise to give you back your conch, and never to interfere with your using it, on one condition, which is this,—whatever you get from it, I am to get double."
"Never!" cried the farmer; "that would be the old business all over again!"
"Not at all!" replied the wily money-lender; "you will have your share! Now, don't be a dog in the manger, for if you get all you want, what can it matter to you if I am rich or poor?"
At last, though it went sorely against the grain to be of any benefit to a money-lender, the farmer was forced to yield, and from that time, no matter what he gained by the power of the conch, the money-lender gained double.

propp_functions.evidence: Unable to use the conch himself, the Money-lender forces the farmer into a deal where he gets double whatever the farmer wishes for.

textSpan.text: He seized the conch, blew it loudly, and cried out, "Oh, Ram! I wish to be blind of one eye!

propp_functions.evidence: The farmer wishes to lose one eye, knowing the Money-lender will lose both (double).

textSpan.text: And so he was, in a twinkling, but the money-lender of course was blind of both, and in trying to steer his way between the two new wells, he fell into one, and was drowned.

propp_functions.evidence: The Money-lender is blinded and accidentally dies as a direct result of his own greed and the farmer's wish.
